dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECTS
dialogues.text: - of star-studded heavens at night.  Scattered cumulus clouds alternately obscure and disclose a three-quarter moon and vast open deeps of glittering constellations. The music diminishes and backs the voice of the narra- tor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since the beginning of Time the people of our Earth have looked upon the stars and pondered - They wondered what man- ner of man - or creature - inhabited the faint mysterious worlds that lay beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large telescope pivoting against the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Astronomers - adjusting eye-pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the largest telescopes have failed to penetrate the dark and awe- some secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White haired astronomer - peering into the eye-piece of a telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men still probe the deeps of space - men of all ages - seeking the answer. 5.    INT. DAVID MacLEAN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT - CLOSE SHOT of telescope - DOLLY BACK to disclose David MacLean - a twelve year old boy, who is sitting on the floor with his eyes glued to a telescope.  He is dressed in rumpled pajamas.  A student lamp on the floor lights the scene in low key.  A star map and nauti- cal almanac lay on the floor in high key under the lamp.  A small Cairn terrier named Cricket stares up at him with wistful curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as David moves back from the telescope and rubs his eyes with his knuckles.  He leafs through the nautical almanac and reaches for the aluminum can- teen on the window sill.  It falls to the floor with a clatter.  He picks it up quickly and listens ap- prehensively for an indication that he has awakened his parents; sighs with relief and glances at an alarm clock on the window sill which reads 3:40. He unscrews the canteen stopper and tilts it to drink; then stops as a bright light illuminates the darkness outside the window.

dialogues.speaker: EFFECTS
dialogues.text: David's angle - through window, of a swiftly descend- ing ball of brilliant white fire as it sweeps down out of the heavens, hovers for a moment, then drops behind foreground trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David - his face highlighted by the ball of fire as he stares with incredible bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with awe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - Gee Whiz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David crosses to foot of bed, puts on his bathrobe and slippers; climbs through the window, chirping at the dog, Cricket, who hops up on the window sill and follows him out. 10.    EXT. BACK OF MacLEAN'S HOUSE - FIELD IN B.G. - NIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as David turns and looks at the dog, who growls and trots toward the field.  David follows him toward field, but stops suddenly. 11.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - SHOOTING AWAY FROM HOUSE - NI (SPECIAL EFFECTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sees a brilliant white light glow suddenly in the distance.  It casts a gigantic black shadow of a thing that could be a man against the flank of the dark hill.  The light goes out suddenly and a strange humming sound fills the air. 12.    EXT. BACK OF MacLEAN'S HOUSE - NIGHT - REVERSE MED

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: David reacts with amazement to what he has seen, he turns and runs toward house followed by Cricket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as the dog jumps through the window, followed by David, who grabs a flashlight.  CAMERA PANS with David as he exits into the hall. 14.    INT. MR. &. MRS. MacLEAN'S BEDROOM - (LOW KEY) - N

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David bursts through the door and shines the flash- light on the bed and his father and mother sit up. MacLean fumbles for the table light and shades his eyes against the flashlight.  He turns on the light. MRS. MacLEAN (with concern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, David?  Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad - listen!  I saw a - a - a some- thing - just landed in our field. A flying saucer or something! MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A space ship - I think.  It's there now - over by the hill.  Come on, Dad. MacLEAN (with weary exasper- ation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone completely crazy - four o'clock in the morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Dad - I saw it - I tell you ... MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you had a dream, dear - a night- mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't asleep!  I saw it -- it landed in our field! MacLEAN (putting his feet on floor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Dad ... MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, march!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving, followed by Cricket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, gee! (he slams door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacLean gets up and puts on his slippers. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, John, don't scold him.  He didn't mean to slam the door. MacLEAN (walking towards door and yawning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not - I'm just going to see that he goes to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is standing by the window, staring out.  Cricket has his forepaws on the window-sill.  The door opens, David turns and looks at his father guiltily as he closes the door.  MacLean indicates the bed with his thumb.  With a sigh, David shucks off his bathrobe and slippers and crawls into the bed.  Cricket jumps onto the foot of the bed.  MacLean crosses to a wardrobe chest and selects a medicine bottle and a spoon from the top of it.  He returns and sits on the side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sick! MacLEAN (shakes bottle and pours into spoon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know - this is some of that stuff Doctor Weber left to make you sleep when you had the flu.  Come on - open up. David looks at his father with exasperated patience and with a shrug of martyrdom swallows the medicine and drops back on his pillow. MacLEAN (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what makes you think you saw a flying saucer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising on elbows, try- ing to convince him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think, Dad - I know - I -- MacLean, with a smile, pushes him back on the pillow. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it was one of the experiment- al rockets from over at White Sands - (David shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything had fallen in the field - I'd have heard it, wouldn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't fall, Dad - it landed over in the field.  Blossom!  Gee, Dad, Blossom's out there!  We'd better go get her! MacLean regards the boy with a patient affectionate smile. MacLEAN (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blossom is an intelligent cow - she can take care of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Dad -- MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been reading too many of those Science Stories - flying saucers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I saw it!  And Cricket saw it - he growled! MacLEAN (fondling the dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He growls at hoot owls too - and shadows!  And I want you to stop growling at shadows and go to sleep. David stares at him with patient resignation. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning I'll take my 12 gauge and you take your .410 and you and I and Cricket will go out in that field and if there's any space ship or flying saucer out there, we'll take a shot at it - especially if they've bothered our cow! David, feeling the effects of the sedative, yawns again.  His father runs his fingers lightly through David's hair in a soothing fashion. MacLEAN (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good boy - go to sleep. David's eyes close and MacLean gets up softly, tiptoes to the light-switch and turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - NIGHT - LONG SHOT Nothing is moving, the bellow of a cow is HEARD over scene. 17.    INT. MR. & MRS. MacLEAN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT - MED. S (Very low key) - Moonlight through bedroom window - Mrs. MacLean's voice comes over scene with alarmed insistence. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John! -- John! -- MacLEAN (annoyed and sleepy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what's the matter? Off scene is HEARD the low mournful bellowing of a cow. The light goes on, revealing MacLean irritably rubbing his eyes. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cow - something's wrong with her. The cow's mooing rises to a terrified bellowing. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably caught in the fence. He gets up, puts on his shoes and bathrobe and takes a flashlight. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry she may be hurt! As MacLean exits -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - NIGHT - MED. SHOT MacLean enters carrying lighted flashlight.  He walks toward sound of bellowing and disappears behind bushes. Bellowing suddenly stops.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: 19.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - MORNING - LONG SHOT MacLean house in background.  David and Cricket, in foreground, are walking hesitantly into the field. There is a sudden high-frequency hum and both David and the dog stare at the ground, which trembles slightly.  David turns and runs toward the house, fol- lowed by Cricket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20.    EXT. FRONT OF MacLEAN HOUSE - MORNING - MED. SHOT A police car stands in front of the house and two of- ficers stand on the front porch, talking to Mrs. Mac- Lean. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and I can't understand what hap- pened to him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say he's been gone for ... David and Cricket run into scene. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathlessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - over there in the field - I heard something - I mean - it was more like I felt something. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - a kind of buzzing sound deep down under the ground. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David, this is no time to let your imagination run away with you when I'm so concerned about your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we'll find him, Mrs. MacLean.  Come on Blaine. They exit from the porch.  Mrs. MacLean and David look after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Blaine and Jackson are walking through the field. They stop and look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cow may have trampled him - they can be dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take the north side, and I'll look over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. 22.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - FULL SHOT - as the two men separate and walk toward hill.  The CAMERA STAYS with Blaine, who stops and looks at some- thing in the grass. 23.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Blaine looking at flashlight in the grass. 24.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - CLOSE SHOT - of flashlight lying in the grass.  Blaine's hand reaches into scene and picks it up. 25.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Blaine straightens up with flashlight and calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jackson!  Here's a flashlight! - he looks around for Jackson.  His face registers be- wilderment. 26.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - BLAINE'S ANGLE - the CAMERA REVEALS an empty field with no possible place of concealment. 27.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jackson -- ! He runs toward the spot where he last saw Jackson.  He stops and looks uncertainly..... 28.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - FULL SHOT Blaine - with hill in background.  He stares about him in puzzled incredulity.  Then a four foot round section of turf immediately behind him raises up about a foot. 29.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - CLOSE SHOT Blaine's face - as he emits a choking scream and drops out of scene. CAMERA PANS down to ground and we see a section of turf closing like the lid of a trap door spider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - FULL SHOT Mrs. MacLean is pacing nervously and David stands look- ing out of the front window.  Cricket is in the room. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they've been gone over an hour. Let me go look, too, Mom - please! MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay right here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, gee -- MacLEAN'S VOICE (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any chance of getting a cup of coffee? Mrs. MacLean and David turn toward doorway. 31.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - MED. SHOT - John MacLean is standing in the living room doorway. He is wearing his bathrobe and pajamas.  He looks some- what disheveled.  Over scene Mrs. MacLean and David speak together. MRS. MacLEAN and DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John! -- Dad! -- 32.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - MED. SHOT - as Mrs. MacLean and David rush toward MacLean. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, John, where have you been?  I've been so worried!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Dad, what happened? Cricket looks at MacLean and crawls under the sofa. MacLean looks down at his wife and son.  His face is tense and he wears a tight forced smile. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to get excited about.  Tell you all about it when I've had my coffee. MacLean crosses and sits in an armchair. MRS. MacLEAN (exiting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just be a minute. David leans over the back of his father's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What took you so long? MacLEAN (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for Blossom.  I followed her trail but finally lost track of her in those scrub oak flats behind Blue Hill. 33.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - CLOSE SHOT David's face - as he stares down at the back of his father's head. 34.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - REVERSE CLOSE SHO David's angle - of back of MacLean's head. There is a livid red scar the size of a quarter on the back of his head just above the nape of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, Dad, what happened to your head? 35.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - MED. CLOSE SHOT A shadow of anger crosses MacLean's face. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a scratch.  Caught it on a barbed wire fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barbed wire fence?  But how could -- MacLEAN (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on out and play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But - Dad -- MacLean suddenly slaps the boy a vicious backhand blow across the face, as Mrs. MacLean enters the scene from background, carrying a cup of coffee.  Mrs. MacLean drops the cup, registering horrified incredulity. David staggers across the room and fetches up against the wall.  Mrs. MacLean crosses to him, puts her arms around him with a sheltering attitude.  Cricket comes out from under the sofa and growls at MacLean and hud- dles near David. MacLEAN (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now will you go out and play -- and take that animal with you! 36.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - MED. CLOSE SHOT David, his mother - with Cricket huddled close by. They stare at MacLean with incredulous baffled expres- sions. MRS. MacLEAN (in a low, hurried voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, David -- do as your father says. 37.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - MED. SHOT David goes out through the hall followed by Cricket. We HEAR the front door slam.  MacLean turns to his wife. MacLEAN (in a cold mechanical voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still waiting for my coffee. MRS. MacLEAN (in a tone of hurt be- wilderment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, John? What's happened? MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a cup of coffee! Mrs. MacLean exits, looking apprehensively over her shoulder at her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38.    EXT. MacLEAN FRONT PORCH - MID-MORNING - FULL SHOT Jackson, Blaine and MacLean are exiting onto the front porch.  David is sitting on the steps with Cricket. Mrs. MacLean stands nervously twisting her apron, look- ing through the front screen door from the hallway. MacLEAN (he now speaks normally and seems like his old self)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks, gentlemen, I won't keep you any longer.  I'm sure you have important things to take care of --- 39.    EXT. MacLEAN FRONT PORCH - DAY - CLOSE SHOT High angle - back of Jackson's head - as he removes cap and wipes forehead with handker- chief.  A livid round red scar is on the back of his head just above the nape of his neck. 40.    EXT. MacLEAN FRONT PORCH - DAY - REVERSE CLOSE SHO David's face - puzzled - he reacts to what he has seen. 41.    EXT. MacLEAN FRONT PORCH - DAY - MED. SHOT Jackson, Blaine and MacLean - from David's angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with meaning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  We have -- Jackson nods his head. 42.    EXT. MacLEAN FRONT PORCH - DAY - CLOSE SHOT Mrs. MacLean staring at her husband with nervous incred- ulity. 43.    EXT. MacLEAN FRONT PORCH - DAY - FULL SHOT Blaine and Jackson - as they leave the porch.  Jackson leans over and ruffles David's hair as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy on those comic books, youngster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they walk toward car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- that imagination of yours is liable to get you in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: 44.    EXT. BACK OF MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - MED. SHOT Small hummock in foreground - MacLean home in background. The hummock is thickly grown with bushes. The leaves of a bush are pushed slowly back and the eye- piece of a one-inch telescope pushes full INTO CAMERA. 45.    EXT. BACK OF MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - CLOSE SHOT David is lying on the ground behind the bushes looking through the telescope.  Cricket is with him. David - raises his face from the eye-piece and looks over the telescope with interest and consternation. He then looks back through telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little girl, Kathy Wilson, aged five, walks across the field picking flowers.  Suddenly a round section of the earth opens up behind her and an indistinct some- thing grabs her by the ankles and snatches her down in- to the hole.  A flap of earth closes back over the hole. 47.    EXT. BACK OF MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - PAN SHOT David and Cricket - as David jumps up, runs toward the field, stops with indecision, then turns and runs fran- tically toward the house, followed by the dog. 48.    INT. HALLWAY - MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - MED. SHOT - as David and Cricket enter and David starts toward the telephone.  Then he looks over his shoulder toward the living room and stops. 49.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - MED. SHOT David's angle - John MacLean - sitting rigidly in a chair in the living room staring fixedly at David. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - what do you want! 50.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - CLOSE SHOT Shooting toward David and Cricket in hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitatingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I was looking for Mom. MacLEAN (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not here.  What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - uh -- nothing -- MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing -- just playing. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother told you not to play in the field, didn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitatingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But - I - uh -- MacLEAN (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you you can play in the field -- all you want - understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He turns and starts toward the front door, Cricket at his heels. 51.    INT. MacLEAN LIVING ROOM - DAY - CLOSE SHOT MacLean - as he picks up a map which he's holding in his lap and studies it intently.  His head jerks up as the front screen door slams.  He looks out the window. 52.    EXT. FRONT - MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - LONG SHOT Through window - David and Cricket - running down road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small cottage with an old fashioned storm cel- lar door leading into the basement adjacent to back steps.  David and Cricket walk into scene.  David knocks on the door, which opens.  David walks in.  Cricket waits outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wilson dries her hands on her apron and pushes back a strand of hair from her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - hello - David --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wilson - is Mr. Wilson home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why -- no, David -- he's out of town. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I mean -- you know your little girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with instant alarm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has something happened to Kathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I mean -- gee, Mrs. Wilson -- You see, I was up on the hill with my telescope -- hiding in the bushes and -- Mrs. Wilson's face darkens with frightened suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were hiding in the bushes and what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I -- I was watching the field and I saw Kathy.  She was picking flowers -- I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then -- well - the ground opened up and something grabbed her and pulled her down into a hole. - as she reacts with annoyance and disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David, stop all this nonsense. Where is she? David backs away from Mrs. Wilson, who advances threat- eningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest, Mrs. Wilson, there's some- thing out there under the ground. It's a space ship or ....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a ship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A space ship! Mrs. Wilson bursts into nervous laughter and grabs David by the shoulders and shakes him severely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, David -- what have you done to my little girl -- where is she -- answer me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest, Mrs. Wilson -- the ground opened up - and -- Mrs. Wilson slaps him sharply.  David raises his elbow to ward off further blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me what you've done to Kathy! The sound of the back kitchen door opening causes Mrs. Wilson to look over her shoulder and react with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy Wilson is entering the kitchen.  She stops and looks at her mother curiously.  Mrs. Wilson rushes across the room and gathers the child in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy, honey -- where have you been? What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY AND MRS. WILSON
dialogues.text: Kathy looks up at her mother with a round cherubic baby face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blandly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David!  How could you! She puts Kathy down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sidles around and attempts to get a look at the back of Kathy's head.  She puts her hands to the back of her head and smoothes her hair down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean -- coming in here and scaring me to death -- What's the matter with you, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, too -- I'm sorry I lost my temper. She turns and reaches for the cookie box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here - don't you want some cookies -- and a glass of milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting toward kit- chen door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really very sorry, David, for the way I treated you -- but after all -- Here, dear -- take some cookies with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry. At this point, he's reached the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cricket is barking frantically at a column of smoke that issues from the open cellar door.  David comes out of kitchen door, sees the smoke coming from the cellar, and calls back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wilson -- Mrs. Wilson -- your house is on fire! Mrs. Wilson runs to the screen door and exits, carrying Kathy with her into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke is pouring out the cellar door.  Mrs. Wilson places Kathy on the ground, then snatches a garden hose and runs to a faucet near the back porch.  She fumbling- ly attempts to attach it, just as a neighbor, Arthur Turner, a man about forty-five, runs into scene.  He quickly attaches the hose, while David points the nozzle toward the cellar door.  He turns on the water, then runs and takes the hose from David, adjusts the nozzle to spray, then, ducking his head against the billowing smoke, enters the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Turner directs the spray of water into the cellar, we can see red tongues of flame diminish.  He advances into the cellar.  Mrs. Wilson is frantically trying to peer through the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better call the fire depart- ment, Mrs. Wilson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling through smoke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Turner, shall I call the fire department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I've got it under control. Mrs. Wilson steps back and sighs with relief.  Kathy crosses to her mother and stands pressed against her mother's legs, calmly watching the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as David sidles around Kathy and looks at the back of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as Turner backs up out of the cellar, coughing.  He is turning off the hose at the nozzle as he exits.  He drops the hose, crosses to the faucet and turns off the valve.  He takes out a handkerchief and dabs at his streaming eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mrs. Wilson.  It's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank heavens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone spilled a gallon can of gaso- line down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible - We keep our spare gasoline in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- a can of gasoline was laying over on its side down there with the top off.  That's what was burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy, were you down in the cellar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blandly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mamma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy's face -- as her eyes look up and meet David's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David -- staring intently at Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy -- as she smiles faintly and her eyes take on a curious, hard, triumphant expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - with telephone booth in foreground.  David enters scene, followed by Cricket.  They go into phone booth and David closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David drops a nickel in the coin box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State 4-3559, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His secretary, a woman of indeterminate age, wearing horn-rimmed spectacles, is speaking on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, David, but Professor Kelston is out.  Is there any mes- sage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know when he'll be back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not expected until late this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gee ... Never mind.  Thank you. David hangs up and is about to leave the booth when he sees his father enter the grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - MacLean buying a pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sees MacLean and crouches down behind the solid panel of the phone booth door.  He holds Cricket to keep him from barking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacLean - turns and leaves scene, walking past phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as the door opens and David peeps out.  Then he and Cricket emerge.  David stops, pauses with indecision. His decision crystalizes into resolution.  He sets his chin and compresses his lips and walks quickly out of scene, followed by Cricket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Cricket stand staring up at the desk sergeant, who speaks in an exasperated tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' ya the Chief of Police don't see nobody without their first statin' the nature of their business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleadingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've gotta see him -- it's im- portant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it's so important -- why can't ya tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause -- (he pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you wouldn't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what makes ya think the Chief would believe ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the trouble, Finley? CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to include a jovial, middle-aged, heavy-set man standing in a half-open doorway.  The door is lettered "CHIEF OF POLICE."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, this kid here claims he's got something very important, but he won't tell me what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the Chief of Police, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Come in, son. David crosses and enters the Chief's office, followed by Cricket.  The door closes behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief crosses and sits in a swivel chair at his desk.  He indicates a chair for David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, young man -- Now, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David MacLean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's so important, David? David looks apprehensively, clears his throat and starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, sir -- it started last night when I was looking through my telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief is listening intently, leaning his hand on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and that's the truth, sir.  Every word of it -- and I know they're under there because I've seen them. CAMERA DOLLIES back to TWO SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after people've been down there -- they act different, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -- very different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your telephone number, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster 6397. The Chief reaches over and picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in alarm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not going to call my father -- Please!  Please! The Chief of Police swings around in his swivel chair and speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster 6397. He looks over his shoulder at David, who is nervously biting his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take it easy, son. Then he turns back to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is staring at the back of the Chief's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the back of the Chief's head there is a round, red, livid spot just above the nape of the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David reacts to what he has seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a rather barren room, with a bench and a straight back chair.  David stands at the window, star- ing through the heavy wire grill.  His lips tremble and his face is pinched and white, and terror lives in his eyes.  Startled, he looks over his shoulder at the sound of the door opening.  He turns and stands at bay. He picks up Cricket and backs against the wall next to the window. MacLEAN'S VOICE (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John MacLean stands near the open door.  His face bears a sad, resigned expression.  The Chief of Police stands with his hands clasped behind his back.  He is benign and kindly in his attitude.  Dr. James Blake, a well- favored young man in his early thirties, stands looking at David with a friendly, gracious smile.  Next to him, Patricia Collins smiles down at David with affectionate concern.  She is dressed in a nurse's blue cape, and the stiff white cuffs and uniform collar are apparent below and above the cape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, David, I'm Doctor Blake. David stares up at him, tight-mouthed and tight-lipped. Pat advances and tries to put her hand on David's shoul- der.  He pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be afraid of, David, this is Miss Collins. David stares up at his father, then at the Chief of Pol- ice, then back to Dr. Blake.  He starts to back away but Pat's arm restrains him gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's going to hurt you. MacLEAN (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. David looks up at his father. MacLEAN (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are going to take you to a -- school -- for a little while -- it's for your own good.  Understand? I'll take care of the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to take Cricket. He makes a dash for the outer door.  MacLean steps for- ward and grabs his wrist and holds it with unnecessary force.  David winces.  Dr. Blake steps forward quickly, glances curiously at MacLean and detaches his fingers from the boy's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, David.  You can bring your dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a scared voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't understand why -- ? Pat crosses and inserts David's arm through hers and pats his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, David.  Your father knows what's best.  We're going to be good friends.  Just wait and see! Dr. Blake opens the door with one hand -- casually takes David's arm and they swiftly exit with him out into the hall, closing the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign reading "MENTAL WARD."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is seated in a large, comfortable overstuffed chair.  A practically empty plate of sandwiches stands on a coffee table next to the chair.  David feeds a piece of sandwich to Cricket.  Pat, who has removed her cape and is now wearing a starched R.N. cap, enters the scene with three paper cartons of malted milk.  Dr. Blake has removed his coat and is seated on a sofa fac- ing David.  Pat passes one of the containers to Dr. Blake, who opens the top and inserts a straw.  She hands the other one to David, then sits on the sofa near the Doctor and starts drinking her malted milk. David is in a much better frame of mind than in the preceding scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --- and that's what happened -- Look, Doctor, if you'd talk to my mother, she'll tell you about my father -- about how he's changed and everything. Pat and Blake exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good idea, David -- in fact -- I had already thought of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've talked to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only over the phone.  She ought to be here any minute now -- you know, that's a very interesting story you just told us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resignedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you don't believe me, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't go so far as to say that.  Better say I'm keeping an open mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no scars on the back of my head, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor mine. David looks at their heads, then sits back with relief and takes a slow meditative pull on his malted milk straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, and Mrs. MacLean enters.  She looks around, sees no one, crosses to desk and taps the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look up at the sound of the bell.  Blake rises and crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacLean? MRS. MacLEAN'S VOICE (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you come in?  I'm Dr. Blake. Mrs. MacLean enters.  David jumps up from the chair and runs to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Mom -- I'm glad you're here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Miss Collins. Mrs. MacLean looks down and smiles brittlely.  Then she coldly detaches his hands from her arm. MRS. MacLEAN (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.  Sit down, David. David stares at her, backs away and slowly sits back in the chair.  Mrs. MacLean's face is calm and composed and her manner brightly pleasant, almost to the point of in- congruity.  She wears a light coat with a high collar and carries a purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you sit down, Mrs. McLean? MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.  My husband's waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David tells me -- MRS. MacLEAN (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what David's been telling you.  He's always been highly im- aginative, and we've had a great deal of trouble with him -- especi- ally since he got that telescope and has been reading those trashy science fiction magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Science fiction? MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- horrible, weird things with pictures of monsters that come in space ships from other planets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see -- and he's discussed these stories with you? MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incessantly.  He's gotten completely beyond our control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with decision)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mrs. MacLean -- I'm sure we'll be able to help him. Mrs. MacLean turns and looks at David with unsympathetic eyes. MRS. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you be a good boy -- and do what the doctor tells you. She walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stares incredulously at his mother.  His eyes focus on the back of her head as she walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's angle of Mrs. MacLean's head.  The back of her head is concealed by her hair and the high collar of her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks up quickly at Dr. Blake, who is also look- ing at Mrs. McLean's head as she opens the door and exits.  Dr. Blake's and David's eyes meet in a curious look of understanding.  Dr. Blake takes a notebook and pencil from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you any relatives, David -- around here, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Just my Aunt Margaret -- but she lives over in Crystal Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name and address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Margaret MacLean - 926 Drexel Avenue - Crystal Falls -- Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just in case something comes up. (he squeezes David's shoulder reassuringly) We'll work this out together, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake exchanges a meaningful look at Pat.  He crosses to an end table and picks up some magazines, which he hands to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued) Mind amusing yourself for a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the latest issues of Look and Life.  We'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake and Pat exit into laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake and Pat enter.  Pat looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) That woman's a cold-blooded per- son if I ever saw one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too cold-blooded.  You know, dear, I think that boy is tell- ing the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But surely you don't believe -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the desk and punches an automatic tele- phone directory list, then dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart Kelston.  David says he's a very good friend of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he dials) You don't expect to find him at the observatory at this time of night, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when astronomers work, my dear. (into phone) Hello -- Professor Kelston, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat sits beside Blake, placing her hand upon his shoulder affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Stu -- Jim Blake --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelston is a lean, sandy-haired, angular man with a pleasant Scandinavian face and a slow, pedantic method of speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jim.  Who?  Yes, I know him -- (pauses) No -- I'd say just the opposite -- Matter of fact, I think he has the makings of a first-rate scientist. (chuckles) Of course I mean astronomer. What other science is there?... Why, certainly -- come on up to the main entrance and ring the night bell -- Right.  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone and assumes a thoughtful, puzzled expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sign reading:  "HERALD-NEWS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph Pulzer, a dignified middle-aged gentleman, is seated at his desk, talking to John MacLean, who is standing looking down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging his shoulders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it!  In the first place I gave up leg work several years ago, and in the second place, I don't see why you can't give me some inkling as to what the story is about? MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This story is so important that I am not taking anyone out there except you -- and if you don't want to go, I'll try the editor of the Blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with resignation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. MacLean -- Pick me up at ten o'clock tonight. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be alone.  And the story'd better be worth it. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be - You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CAMERA TRUCKS IN with the car, the headlights illuminate the facade and the heavy bronze door in high key.  The lights cut off and Blake, Pat and David enter the observatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, Blake and David -- The Focault pendulum is in the background.  The interior of the observatory foyer is illuminated in low key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glibly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Focault pendulum.  It de- monstrates the peripherial aberration of axial inclination. Then David realizes he is talking to an amateur. Pat turns and stares at David in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it shows how much the earth is tilting on its axis. At this point, Professor Kelston approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it didn't take you very long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've met Patricia Collins, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  How are you, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you know ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting and af- fectionately putting his hand on David's shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- David and I are old friends. Let's go to my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large scale star maps hang on the walls, interspersed with large photographs of comets, spiral nebulae, solar coronae, various lunar and solar eclipses.  His desk is littered with a miscellaneous array of meteorites, photo- graphs and electrical viewing apparatus for astronomical plates.  Professor Kelston seats himself at his desk, after indicating comfortable chairs in which his visitors dispose themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now -- what's the big mystery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- first we'd like to have a look at the back of your head. A slow smile comes over Kelston's face and his eyes twinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure some of these patients you deal with aren't contagious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight I'm not altogether sure of anything. Blake and David are seated together on a leather divan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- seriously -- you don't happen to have any scars on the back of your head -- do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since football.  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind letting us have a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious? Blake nods in affirmation.  Kelston rises, crosses in front of the desk and turns his head around for inspec- tion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bump of intelligence is prac- tically invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at Kelston's head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Kelston straightens and leans back against the edge of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like David to take it from here. All right, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I -- every time I tell anybody this, they think I'm crazy. (looking up at Blake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is -- I -- I mean I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, David, you go right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- it started last night. I was looking for variables in Orion -- and all of a sudden I saw this bright light --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK from Kelston's face.  He is smoking a pipe and is staring meditatively through the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off scene) -- and everyone of the people that have those scars, behave strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to David) Are you positive that you saw these creatures or whatever they are pull the little Wilson girl under the ground?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -- I wasn't two hundred yards away and I was looking through my one-inch telescope and it's fifty power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far is this field from your house, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a quarter of a mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kelston) Then we could see it from here with the sixteen-inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Yes, sir.  I know we could. (he turns to Kelston) You know that time last summer when you let me look right into the kit- chen window and I could see Mom in there cooking supper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitatingly) That was last summer, David. Since then, because of the top secret experiments at White Sands, the Army has instructed me to allow no one but my staff to use the telescope. (he pauses) But under the circumstances, I'm sure it will be all right.  Let's take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - opening of upper aperture and dome rotating approxi- mately sixty degrees and stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelston, Blake, Pat and David station themselves at Multiple oculars while Kelston focuses instrument with manual verniers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fortunate -- there's plenty of moonlight tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) That's it!  That's where they got Kathy Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) Good heavens!  I never imagined you could see so clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's increase the magnifi- cation so we can get a closer view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telescope zooms into MED. LONG SHOT and sharpens. An automobile comes slowly into the field of vision and stops and the lights are extinguished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Dad's car. A front door of the sedan opens and the dome light il- luminates the interior of the car in comparative high key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get a real close look. The telescope field narrows and brings MacLean and his companion up into a MED. CLOSE SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That looks like Ralph Pulzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The editor of the Herald News?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's who it is -- I know him. Pulzer seems to be discussing something rather vehement- ly with MacLean.  He suddenly shrugs his shoulders, takes a flashlight which MacLean offers him, gets out of the car and closes the door, walks around the car and starts out across the field, lighting his way with the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father stayed in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man's walking right to the place where --- The telescope shot PANS with Pulzer as he ascends a slight rise.  He reaches the top of the mound and stops, turning the flashlight in a slow circle about him, when suddenly the flashlight goes out and all is darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group around telescope.  They look up from the oculars and stare at each other, with speechless amazement. Kelston reaches for the verniers, they look back into the oculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it PANS DOWN to MacLean's automobile just in time to see the headlights turn on and the car move rapidly out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group around telescope.  They look at Kelston with questioning faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) If you'll go back to my office -- I'll join you there in a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake takes Pat's arm and he, Pat and David exit. Kelston crosses to his desk and flips a switch on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom) George.  When did you check the rocket at White Sands last? (pause) No, don't bother -- I'll check it myself as long as I'm up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelston hangs up the intercom, crosses to the switch box and presses a button.  The upper aperture slowly turns on its axis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dome slowly turns on its axis and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelston has just finished swinging the telescope into position.  He looks into the eye piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a giant rocket standing upright in a take-off position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelston steps down from the telescope and crosses to a small desk lighted by a low power student's lamp. He sits down and dials the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, operator.  This is Pro- fessor Stuart Kelston at the Astronomical Observatory.  Get me the White Sands Rocket Proving Station, please. (pause) Hello -- White Sands?  Give me the Security Office. (pause) Hello -- is Colonel Fielding there? (pause) Yes, it's most important. (pause) Hello, Colonel -- this is Stuart Kelston at the Observatory... Operation 925 is with us.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Fielding, head of White Sands Security Division, is seated at his desk talking into the phone.  A keen, executive type man, he is in his shirt sleeves, but in uniform. --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) What?! (pause) Are you sure? (pause) All right, I'll be at your office in the morning -- 9:00 o'clock. Right.  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel hangs up the phone and assumes a thoughtful expression.  He rises and crosses to a filing cabinet, removes a key from his pocket and unlocks the file. He pulls out a drawer from which he takes a manila folder.  He crosses back to his desk, seats himself and then opens the folder - removing some papers.  We DOLLY into an INSERT of the label on the outside of the folder - it reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, David and Blake are on scene.  Kelston enters and crosses behind his desk, opens a drawer and takes out a large scrapbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David) Young man -- it looks like you've stumbled on to something that the government has been concerned about for some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake, Pat and David cross to desk.  Kelston opens scrap- book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen most of these magazine and newspaper stories of so-called flying saucers before - but have you ever seen them compiled in one book?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAPBOOK
dialogues.text: - with clips of flying saucer stories.  CAMERA PANS from one headline to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) When you see them al together, they begin to add up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the authorities have denied all these stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they have -- and they will probably continue to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?  Why not keep the public informed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lack of complete information, I suppose.  And perhaps afraid it would cause panic and hysteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are these space ships from, Professor Kelston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our observations lead us to believe they are from mother ships in free orbit just above Earth's atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where are these mother ships from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows -- we've worked out a postulate and Mars seems to be the logical point of origin.  Step in here and I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelston is seated at the operating console.  Pat, David and Blake are standing by it.  The projector is in back- ground.  Kelston turns a rheostat and the light dims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) That's our planetary system there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (EFFECT SHOT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - of our planetary system on inverted dome of planet- arium.  A white projected arrow indicates each point as Kelston speaks o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) This is the earth moving around the sun on this orbit -- and this is the orbit of Mars.  And here is the rela- tive position of Mars and Earth to- night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Why -- they're our next door neigh- bors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Yes -- only a little over three mil- lion miles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) It would take forever to travel three million miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Hardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene on the planetarium changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our earth is traveling through space at well over a hundred thousand miles an hour.  At that speed, we could reach Mars in thirty days - or they could reach us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't understand -- why don't we burn up from friction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't any atmosphere in space -- therefore -- no friction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why do you think they're from Mars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Because Mars is closer to us than any other planet.  They are now in their winter, and those are polar caps - the same as ours. See how much smaller they are in summer - those dark areas are vegetation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Do they have cities, too -- the same as ours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) If they do, they are underground -- the low oxygen content and extremes of temperature indicate a sub- terranean culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Those things in our pasture are subterranean all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - as the house lights go up.  Kelston sits at the con- trol console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how would Martians have enough intelligence to build space ships?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The human race doesn't have a monopoly on intelligence.  Besides -- Mars is millions of years older than we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what's their reason for travel- ing so far through space?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mars is a dying planet.  They are losing their oxygen and water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this could be the start of an invasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why did they begin here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the operations at White Sands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all they're doing at White Sands is just shooting rockets up into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  Very high up into the air - beyond atmosphere and in- to space.  The scientists at White Sands have developed a rocket powerful enough to take them to these mother ships in outer space.  That rocket is completed and ready to be fired right now.  That may be the Mar- tians objective. (he rises) However, we'll have the answers to a lot of our questions tomorrow. Colonel Fielding, the head of the Security Division will be in my office in the morning.  I'm sure he will want to talk to all of you - can you be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly -- what time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blake, Pat and David rise.  Kelston comes with them to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Robert Fielding is seated at Kelston's desk, talking to Kelston.  Blake, Pat and David are seated on chairs in the office.  David is just hanging up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where they could be.  If they're at home they're not answering the phone -- I called last night and this is the second time this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm, I see.  Come on, young man -- you and I are going out to do a little investigating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we stop by the hospital and get my dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we'd better take the time right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take care of him, David. Blake and David exit.  Kelston stops Fielding at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment, Colonel.  I called Ralph Pulzer's office this morning -- he's left town with Chief of Police Barrows and Detectives Jackson and Blaine -- and they didn't say where they were going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get me a description of all these people?  I'll phone you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122.    EXT. FRONT OF MacLEAN'S HOUSE - DAY - FULL SHOT A Cadillac limousine, with a long whip aerial, pulls up in front of the house and stops.  It is driven by Ser- geant Balardi.  He opens the door and Fielding and David step out.  David runs up the driveway.  Fielding remains standing by the car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, phone Professor Kelston at the Observatory and see if he has that information I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Fielding turns and exits from the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123.    EXT. FRONT OF MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - MED. SHOT David is waiting in the driveway as Fielding joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's take a look inside the house. They walk toward the front door. 124.    EXT. FRONT MacLEAN HOUSE - DAY - MED. CLOSE SHOT Balardi is on the telephone in the car, holding a note- book on his knee and writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  John MacLean, age thirty- five, height, five feet eleven inches, weight, 165, hair, brown. 125.    INT. MacLEAN BEDROOM - DAY - FULL SHOT Fielding is standing in the middle of the room and David is standing before an open closet, very perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perturbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's suitcase is gone, and my father's rifle.  He used to keep it in this closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a rifle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm -- I'd like to talk to someone who -- What about that little girl -- the one you think set fire to her mother's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy Wilson? -- I can take you over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wilson stands on the porch, talking to Fielding, Balardi and David.  She is distraught and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry to hear that, Mrs. Wilson.  When did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the doctor say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said something about a cerebral hemorrhage. (then, semi-hysterically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how a little child could have a thing like that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David - reacting and thinking about his mother and father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wilson, I don't like to disturb you at a time like this -- but there's just one question I'd like to ask you -- Do you have any idea why your lit- tle girl started the fire in the cel- lar yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what started the fire! And I don't know why you have to torture me with a lot of questions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry and I won't bother you any more. David stands frozen, thinking what could happen to his mother and father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you -- come along, David. Mrs. Wilson turns abruptly and enters front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - FULL SHOT Fielding, Balardi and David -- with the bushes in f.g. where David observed Kathy Wilson's capture through his small telescope.  Fielding holds a monocular (Sportscope) in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you point out the place where the Wilson child disappeared? He hands the monocular to David, who adjusts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a slight pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There -- those three white stones are right by the edge of it -- you can even see the crack -- see it over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a look. David hands him the monocular; Fielding looks through it. 130.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - TELESCOPE MATTE SHOT -- a faint crack approximately four feet in diameter is clearly visible near three white stones. 131.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Fielding removes the monocular from his eye and turns to Sergeant Balardi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See those bushes down there -- by the road, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three white stones in the field about one hundred feet from there at two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down behind those bushes -- and when you get there, throw some rocks as close to those three white stones as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever's down there must be sensi- tive to sound -- so keep your distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when I signal you, come back here on the double.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The Sergeant crosses out of scene, and Fielding turns to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just exactly what did this thing look like, son?  The thing that grabbed the little Wilson girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It moved so fast it was hard for me to see exactly what it looked like. 132.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. CLOSE SHOT - BALA He kneels on one knee beside a small pile of stones about the size of peaches.  He takes one in his right hand and hurls it over the bushes as one throws a gren- ade. 133.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Fielding and David -- as Fielding looks through monocu- lar. 134.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MATTE SHOT Through monocular -- of stone falling near the center of the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that one ought to be close enough for them to hear! Another stone falls in the same area, and a circular four-foot section of earth slowly rises about six in- ches, revealing an indistinct shape that moves as though someone or something were peering out of the crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's moving -- but I can't make out what it is! Another stone falls near the trapdoor and it closes swiftly. 135.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Fielding and David.  As Fielding lowers monocular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a trapdoor all right.  Some- thing's in there! David looks at him and nods concerned affirmation. Fielding raises his monocular again and looks toward the bushes where Sergeant Balardi was throwing the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Balardi?  Come on!! He runs toward field, David follows and CAMERA PANS with them. 136.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Fielding and David -- warily approach the bushes behind which the Sergeant was throwing rocks.  Suddenly they stop, staring at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got him!  See there? 137.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - REVERSE CLOSE SHOT Their angle of the faint, circular, four-foot outline near where the Sergeant was last seen.  His military cap lies on the ground and scratches and gouges show where his fingers clawed as he was dragged down into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last one they'll get -- come on, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138.    EXT. MacLEAN FIELD - DAY - MED. SHOT Fielding's car.  Fielding reaches into car and flips the catch on the fish pole antenna, which flies up. David watches with interest as Fielding takes out a phone and pushes the button on the hand set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is WJ605.  Dispatch White Sands, 121A.  Closed circuit. Expedite.  Priority A-14. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Walter? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fielding.  Operation 925 is with us! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure ... Now, hear this -- I want you to muster two platoons and a demolition team, with plenty of C-two charge.  Equip them with sub-machine guns and grenades. Bring the light Sherman tank and get here as fast as you can.  Get rolling.  I'll expect you here by tomorrow at fourteen hundred.  Got that? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rendezvous is at the intersection off State Highway eighty-six and Belle Meade Road.  If any newspaper people ask you any questions, tell them it's a training maneuver. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!  Goodbye. He presses the stud again. WJ605.  Dispatch 143.  Expedite. Closed circuit. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Cagle? -- Fielding..Opera- tion 925... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- Now clear the boards for this...Cover all key supply sources for the White Sands rocket project. (Fielding reading from notebook)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put out an all-points alarm for the following subjects - John MacLean, Age, thirty-five, height, five feet eleven.  Weight, 165, - hair --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLATE GLASS DOOR
dialogues.text: It reads U.S. ARMY INTELLIGENCE - MAJOR G.A. CAGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Cagle is seated at his desk, listening on the phone and writing on a pad.  He is an alert, hawk- eyed man who looks like a successful attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a sharp, incisive manner) Yes, Colonel -- I have it -- John MacLean -- Mary MacLean -- Ralph Pulzer, Chief Fred Barrow, Detectives Jackson and Blaine. (pause) Yes, sir -- all points bulletin. And they are to be returned to Dr. Blake at the County Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone and flips the toggle on an inter- com box on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom) Clear the teletype -- and code this right away with special attention to Armstrong Liquid Oxygen Plant and Belaer Magnesium Plant -- also all other key supply sources for the White Sands Rocket Project.  Get that? (pause) First subject:  John MacLean, age thirty-five, height five feet eleven --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1)  Teletypes. 2)  Hands operating telegraph keys in high speed code. 3)  Telegraph wires - odd angles.

dialogues.speaker: B.G.
dialogues.text: Detectives Blaine and Jackson run toward CAMERA and turn around corner of building and stand flattened against the wall.  CAMERA PANS to Blaine and Jackson. Behind them is sign:  BELAER MAGNESIUM PLANT.  The scene is lighted in low key by street light.  Over scene there is a terrific shattering explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silhouette of the factory is gone.  A siren o.s. builds up to crescendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blaine and Jackson - as they turn and run away from an army military police car that pulls up to the curb.  They turn and run up the alley in the direction from whence they came and the headlights of another military police car come into alley with siren going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Blaine and Jackson huddle back against the wall, caught in the blazing headlights of the two military police cars As a group of soldiers emerge from each car and converge upon Blaine and Jackson with drawn revolvers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS ALONG the woven wire fence and pulls in on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentry - standing guard at which is obviously a side gate.

dialogues.speaker: "ARMSTRONG LIQUID OXYGEN PLANT."
dialogues.text: A small sign underneath reads: "Apply to main gate for admittance."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens up at the sound of a car approaching off scene.  The motor of the car sputters and the headlights pick up the sentry as the forepart of the car moves into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't park here, lady. MARY MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's the matter with my car - I think it's the ignition --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through window of car.  Mary MacLean - speaking to sen- try in background. MARY MacLEAN (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you suppose you could find out what's the matter with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning rifle against fence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not much of a mechanic, lady, but I'll take a look. He crosses to the front of the car and there is a click as Mary MacLean releases the hood catch.  The sentry leans over the motor and turns on his flashlight.  The rear door of the sedan opens and John MacLean moves swiftly around behind the sentry, carrying a rifle. There is a thud as he strikes the sentry over the back of the head with the rifle butt and the sentry falls over the fender of the car unconscious and then falls to the ground.  MacLean closes the hood of the car and drags the sentry over near the fence. MacLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
